newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore editor defends Malaysia crime story.
newsitem.headline: Singapore editor defends Malaysia crime story.

text.p: The editor of the Singapore Straits Times newspaper said on Friday he was sorry a story about crime levels in Malaysia's Johor state offended Malaysians, but said his first duty was to report the facts.
"We are sorry if our story offended anyone in Malaysia but our first duty as a newspaper is to report the facts accurately," editor Leslie Fong told Reuters in a written reply to questions.

Fong said he was puzzled by the angry reactions in Malaysia to the paper's coverage of a High Court hearing on Monday which deleted from court records comments criticising Johor made by Singapore elder statesman Lee Kuan Yew.
Lee, in an affidavit filed in pursuit of a libel case against opposition politician Tang Liang Hong, described Johor as "notorious for shootings, muggings and car-jackings".

A leak of the affidavit, intended to pour scorn on Tang's flight to Johor saying he had received death threats at home following his general election defeat in January, sparked a furious reaction in Kuala Lumpur.
Lee offered unreserved apologies, then promised to have the comments deleted from the record when that failed to cool Malaysian wrath.
On Monday, Lee said his comments were based on newspaper reports about crime in Johor and submitted to the court a compilation of them from the past three years, Fong said.

"We did what any newspaper would have done -- we took a look at the compilation, highlighted some of the more prominent cases and made the observation that anyone reading them might well come to the conclusion that crime was a problem there," he said.
Malaysian ministers slammed the coverage, with International Trade and Industry Minister Rafidah Aziz calling for a media war against Singapore.
"We thought the subject was dead...The government does not want to argue. Why not have a media war?" she said to reporters on Wednesday.

On Thursday, leading Malay daily Utusan Malaysia took up the banner in a sharply critical front page editorial and the New Straits Times daily carried an item about a United Nations report showing crime in Singapore to be higher than in Malaysia.
The Straits Times carried both reports without editorial comment.
Analyst Bruce Gale of the Political Economic Risk Consultancy in Singapore told Reuters he was surprised by the Straits Times coverage of Lee's compilation of crime reports.
"I was a little bit surprised the Straits Times wanted to keep at it," he said.
"What we see in the New Straits Times is a bit tit for tat," he added.
